questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in varicose vein? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duplex scan

 

The investigation of choice for varicose veins is a duplex scan. A duplex scan, also known as a venous Doppler or venous duplex, is a non-invasive ultrasound method that allows visualization of the veins and the blood flow within them. It is particularly useful for identifying the location and extent of venous incompetence, such as at the sapheno-femoral junction and in perforator veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plethysmography: It is not the first-line investigation for varicose veins.

 

Option C. MRI: It may be used in more complex cases where detailed imaging is required.

 

Option D. CT: CT scans are not the primary choice for evaluating varicose veins due to the limited ability to assess venous blood flow and venous incompetence compared to a duplex scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The duplex scan is the investigation of choice for varicose veins, providing detailed information on venous blood flow and identifying sites of venous incompetence.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a 6-year-old child whose head and neck was burnt in an accident at school? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18%

 

As per Lund and Browder chart the percentage of burns in this child would be 18%.

 

For the 1-9 years age group, the Lund-Browder chart is divided into the following regions:

 

  1. Head and Neck: 18%
  2. Anterior Trunk: 18%
  3. Posterior Trunk: 18%
  4. Each Arm: 9%
  5. Each Leg: 14%
  6. Perineum: 1%

 

The Lund-Browder chart is a tool used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) of burns in paediatric patients. It is divided into regions that correspond to different percentages of TBSA, and each region is assigned a different percentage based on the age of the patient. The chart takes into account the fact that the proportion of body surface area represented by different body parts changes as a child grows.

 

The chart is divided into three age groups: 0-1 year, 1-9 years, and 9-17 years. Each age group has its own chart with different regions and percentages. The regions are further divided into sub-regions to allow for more accurate estimation of the TBSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9%: For a 6-year-old child, 9% represents the TBSA of each arm. This does not correspond to the head and neck region.

 

Option C. 27%: There is no single region in the Lund-Browder chart for the 1-9 years age group that accounts for 27% of the TBSA. The head and neck alone are 18%.

 

Option D. 36%: This percentage does not correspond to any single region or combination of the head and neck in the Lund-Browder chart for a child of this age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients.
  • For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA.
  • This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. The patient is conscious, alert, and hemodynamically stable. Upon examination, the patient reports that the pain began suddenly. A chest X-ray is performed, which reveals some abnormal findings. Identify the condition shown below and its management?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • Given the clinical picture of acute-onset severe abdominal pain and a chest X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm, the diagnosis of hollow viscus perforation is suspected, and the appropriate management is an emergency laparotomy.
  • A hollow viscus perforation leads to the spillage of enteric contents into the abdominal cavity. This can cause acute peritonitis, a life-threatening inflammation of the peritoneal cavity.
  • Emergency laparotomy is the surgical opening of the abdomen to investigate and treat the cause of the acute abdominal pain. It can confirm the diagnosis, identify the source of the perforation, and treat it, often by repairing or resecting the affected section of the bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric lavage:

 

  • Gastric lavage, often referred to as "stomach pumping," is a procedure that involves the insertion of a tube into the stomach to remove its contents. It's often used in cases of drug overdose or ingestion of toxic substances.
  • In the context of sudden abdominal pain and air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, this option is not appropriate since the problem is not related to the contents of the stomach but rather a perforation.

 

Option C. Ultrasound:

 

  • While it can be used in the evaluation of various abdominal conditions, in the context of acute severe pain and a suggestive chest X-ray, ultrasound wouldn't be the primary diagnostic modality.
  • Air (as from a perforated viscus) is a poor conductor of ultrasound waves, which makes ultrasound less reliable in this setting compared to other imaging modalities.

 

Option D. Chest tube insertion:

 

  • A chest tube is inserted between the ribs to drain air, blood, or fluid from the pleural space. This is usually done in conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion.
  • While the X-ray may show air under the diaphragm, this air is in the abdomen and not in the pleural space of the chest.
  • Given the acute presentation and the imaging findings, the correct management is emergency laparotomy to address the underlying perforation and prevent further complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.
  • Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.

questions.text: In indirect inguinal hernia surgery, which nerve is most commonly injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genitofemoral

 

In the context of Lichtenstein's hernia repair, which is an open mesh repair for inguinal hernias, the ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely to be injured, it was not listed as an option in this question. Therefore, the genitofemoral nerve is the best answer among the given choices.

 

This is because the genitofemoral nerve runs within the spermatic cord, which can be manipulated during the surgery. During the separation of the hernia sac from the spermatic cord, there is a risk of injuring the genitofemoral nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral: The femoral nerve is too large and lies deeper within the body, making it less likely to be injured during an inguinal hernia repair.

 

Option C. Obturator: The obturator nerve is not typically associated with inguinal hernia anatomy and is not at risk during these surgeries.

 

Option D. Pudendal: The pudendal nerve is related to the pelvic region and is not typically involved in the anatomy of an inguinal hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In open inguinal hernia repairs, particularly Lichtenstein's hernia repair, the ilioinguinal nerve >> genitofemoral nerve is at risk of injury due to its location within the spermatic cord and very rarely iliohypogastric nerve can be injured.

 

In laparoscopic hernia repair, there is a risk of injuring nerves such as the lateral cutaneous nerve, anterior cutaneous nerve, and femoral nerve.

questions.text: The best way to manage the wound shown in the image is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cleaning and dressing

 

The image shows an abrasion. Since it is going to heal with primary intention, no grafting is required.

 

  • Cleaning the wound involves gently removing any debris, foreign material, or contaminants from the wound site. This step helps prevent infection and promotes a healthy healing environment.
  • Dressing the wound involves covering it with a sterile bandage or dressing. Dressings help maintain a moist environment, protect the wound from further contamination, and provide a barrier against external factors.

 

In many cases, initial wound management involves cleaning the wound to prevent infection and applying a sterile dressing. This basic approach is suitable for wounds that are not deeply contaminated, do not require extensive tissue removal (debridement), and do not necessitate advanced interventions like grafting (skin graft or allograft). It provides a clean and protected environment for natural healing to occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Debridement and dressing: Debridement involves the removal of dead or contaminated tissue from the wound, which may be necessary in cases of severe infection or tissue damage. After debridement, the wound is dressed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Here are some general principles for the management of a superficial abrasion:

 

  1. Clean the wound: Gently clean the wound with soap and warm water to remove any dirt or debris. Use a clean cloth or sterile gauze to pat the wound dry.
  2. Apply a dressing: Cover the abrasion with a sterile dressing or adhesive bandage to keep it clean and protected. Change the dressing daily or more often if it becomes wet or dirty.
  3. Manage pain: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  4. Watch for signs of infection: Keep an eye on the abrasion for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, pus, or increasing pain.
  5. Follow up: Depending on the severity of the abrasion, you may need to follow up with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and treatment.

questions.text: Identify the device in the image: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PEG tube

 

The image provided shows a tray containing various instruments, including an introducer, a tube with a bolster, and a guide wire, which are characteristic of a PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube kit. A PEG tube is used for providing nutrition directly into the stomach in patients who cannot swallow food. The distinguishing features of a PEG tube include a retention bolster that secures the tube to the abdominal wall and an inflatable balloon at the end that helps retain the tube within the stomach. The presence of these components in the tray confirms that the  is a PEG tube. This procedure involves making a small incision in the abdomen, inserting the tube, and securing it, which is why the tray includes various tools for this process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NJ tube (Nasojejunal tube): An NJ tube is inserted through the nose and extends into the jejunum. It is typically used for feeding but does not require the surgical kit or bolster shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. NG tube (Nasogastric tube): An NG tube is a simple tube inserted through the nose into the stomach or intestine. Unlike the PEG tube, it does not involve a retention bolster or a complex insertion procedure, making it less likely to require the tools seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Chest drain tube: A chest drain tube is used to remove air, fluid, or pus from the pleural space in the chest. It typically does not include the bolster and balloon characteristic of a PEG tube, and the tools in the image do not match those used for chest drainage procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The PEG tube is a specialized device used for long-term feeding directly into the stomach, identified by its retention bolster and the presence of specific tools in the insertion kit. Understanding the key components of the PEG tube kit helps differentiate it from other types of medical tubes

choices.text: Wide excision of the lactiferous duct.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure that involves the removal of a small segment of the lactiferous duct, typically from the breast in which a probe is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging. A tennis racquet incision is made, and the flap is dissected to reach the duct. The duct is then excised. This procedure is known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Microdochectomy

 

  • Microdochectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing a discharging lactiferous duct.
  • The procedure is typically performed on patients with duct papilloma or duct ectasia involving a single duct.
  • During the procedure, a probe or stiff nylon suture is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging.
  • An incision can be made in the shape of a tennis racquet to encompass the entire duct, or a periareolar incision may be used to access the duct by dissecting the nipple flap.
  • The affected duct is then excised or removed, and the tissue is sent for further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macrodochectomy: Macrodochectomy refers to the removal of a larger or major segment of the lactiferous duct. This procedure can be undertaken when there are multiple pathologies within the duct, making it necessary to excise a more substantial portion of the duct system.

 

Option C. Cone excision: In breast surgery, it might mean the removal of a cone-shaped segment of tissue which includes a problematic area, such as a localized tumor. The goal is often to ensure that the margins of the removed tissue are clear of any pathological changes.

 

Option D. Wide excision of the lactiferous duct: This procedure involves removing a more extensive portion of the lactiferous duct, typically more than in a microdochectomy. The objective here might be to ensure that the entirety of a problematic duct or surrounding tissue is removed, especially if there is a concern about a larger segment of the duct being involved with a disease process.

 

Educational Objective:


Microdochectomy is the surgical removal of a discharging lactiferous duct, commonly performed for cases of single-duct pathologies like duct papilloma or duct ectasia.

questions.text: A patient presents with a slowly progressive swelling that has been noticeable for the past 18 months. The swelling exhibits variable consistency, with some areas feeling hard and others feeling soft, image of patient is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Explanation:

 

The case scenario and image showing a swelling lifting the ear lobe are suggestive of a pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign tumors of the salivary glands, with the parotid gland being the most frequent site. These tumors are encapsulated and exhibit a mixed cellular composition, leading to a variable consistency, which is reflected in their name "pleomorphic." Clinically, they present as painless, slow-growing masses. The characteristic lift of the earlobe due to the swelling is a classic sign of a parotid gland tumor. Untreated pleomorphic adenomas may undergo malignant transformation, hence surgical excision is typically recommended.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Jaw Tumor: Jaw tumors, particularly those of the mandible or maxilla, are often bony growths or related to the teeth (odontogenic tumors). While they can cause facial asymmetry, they are usually centered around the bones and are not typically located in the parotid gland region. These tumors tend to be hard and lack the variable consistency described in the clinical presentation.

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts are benign cystic tumors containing skin appendages (such as hair follicles), and sometimes hair, teeth, or sebum. They are typically congenital and found on the face, neck, or ovary. While they can appear on the face or neck, the described clinical presentation is less suggestive of a dermoid cyst compared to a pleomorphic adenoma. Dermoid cysts often show indentation due to putty material.

 

Option D. Sebaceous cyst: Also known as an epidermal cyst, a sebaceous cyst is a benign growth arising from blocked sebaceous glands, often containing a thick, cheese-like material. Sebaceous cysts can appear almost anywhere on the body where sebaceous glands are found, including the face, and often show a black punctum. However, the described clinical presentation and duration better match a pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands, typically presenting as a painless, slow-growing mass with variable consistency and often lifting the earlobe due to its location in the parotid gland.

questions.text: Identify the level of amputation: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Below Knee

 

The correct answer is Below Knee amputation. In the provided image, the amputation level shows both the tibia and fibula bones, indicating that the amputation is below the knee. A below knee amputation preserves the knee joint, which is crucial for improved mobility and prosthetic fitting compared to an above knee amputation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Above Knee: In an above knee amputation, only the femur would be visible as the amputation occurs above the knee joint, which is not the case in the image provided.

 

Option C. Lis Franc: A Lis Franc amputation is a type of foot amputation that involves the tarsometatarsal joints.

 

Option D. Chopart: A Chopart amputation involves a disarticulation through the midfoot, specifically at the talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints. The image does not show the foot structures required for a Chopart amputation, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a below knee amputation, both the tibia and fibula bones are visible, distinguishing it from above knee and foot-level amputations like Lis Franc and Chopart.

questions.text: Name the material which is used for Lichtenstein mesh repair:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polypropylene

 

The material used for Lichtenstein mesh repair is polypropylene, commonly referred to as Prolene mesh. It is a non-absorbable synthetic mesh, meaning it remains in the body permanently to provide ongoing support to the repaired area. The Lichtenstein repair technique is commonly used in hernia surgery to provide a tension-free repair by reinforcing the weakened area with this mesh.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyglycolic acid: This is incorrect because polyglycolic acid is an absorbable suture material and not suitable for long-term reinforcement as required in mesh repair.

 

Option C. Polyacrylamide: This is incorrect because polyacrylamide is not used in surgical mesh repairs.

 

Option D. Polygalactin: This is incorrect as polygalactin (Vicryl) is also an absorbable material used primarily for suturing, not for permanent mesh repair.

 

Extra edge:

 

In intraperitoneal repair, IPOM (Intraperitoneal onlay mesh), the mesh that you use is called a dual mesh or a composite mesh. So it will have proline on one side, it will have a collagen or a Teflon on the other side. So it has two surfaces, one surface facing upwards towards the peritoneum, one surface facing downwards towards the intestines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polypropylene mesh is the material of choice for Lichtenstein mesh repair due to its non-absorbable nature, providing long-term reinforcement for hernia repairs.

choices.text: A, B, C and D

questions.text: Which of the following are used to stop esophageal variceal bleed? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and C

 

 A, B, C can be used to stop esophageal variceal bleed.

 

 A: Sengstaken Blakemore tube

 

 B: Minnesota tube

 

 C: Gastric endoscope

 

A. Sengstaken Blakemore Tube:

 

  • The Sengstaken Blakemore tube is a medical device used for emergency management of esophageal and gastric variceal bleeding by causing balloon tamponade effect, typically associated with liver cirrhosis.
  • It consists of three lumens: one for inflation of esophageal and gastric balloons each and one for aspiration of gastric contents

 

B. Minnesota Tube:

 

  • Similar to SB tube, this has 4 channels, additionally for esophageal aspiration. It is also used for balloon tamponade.

 

C. Gastric Endoscope:

 

  • A gastric endoscope, also known as a gastroscopy or upper endoscopy, is a flexible tube with a camera at the end used for examining the esophagus, stomach, and the beginning of the small intestine.
  • It is primarily a diagnostic tool which can also be used for therapeutic interventions like variceal banding or sclerotherapy.

 

Other option:

 

D. Fiberoptic Bronchoscope:

 

  • A fiberoptic bronchoscope is a medical instrument used for examining the airways and lungs. It consists of a flexible tube with a light source and a camera that is passed through the nose or mouth into the trachea and bronchi.
  • It is used for diagnostic and therapeutic procedures related to the respiratory system, such as visualizing and obtaining samples from the airways, removing foreign bodies, and managing airway issues.

choices.text: Radical nephrectomy with immediate renal transplantation

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a single kidney presents with a solitary exophytic mass of 4 cm localized at its lower pole. Which amongst the following is the best-recommended management option:(NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Partial nephrectomy

 

Explanation:

 

Partial nephrectomy is the preferred surgical treatment for small, localized renal tumors, particularly in patients with a solitary kidney. This approach helps to preserve renal function while effectively treating the cancer. Radical nephrectomy would result in the patient requiring dialysis or transplantation, which carries a higher risk and greater impact on the patient's quality of life.

 

Rationale:

 

  • Partial nephrectomy: For tumors ≤4 cm, partial nephrectomy is recommended because it offers equivalent cancer-specific survival rates compared to radical nephrectomy while better preserving renal function.
  • Radical nephrectomy: Although this procedure is effective in treating renal cell carcinoma, it is not the best option for patients with a solitary kidney due to the risk of renal failure and the need for dialysis or transplantation.
  • Radical nephrectomy with dialysis: This would significantly impact the patient's quality of life and is not necessary for a small, localized tumor that can be managed with partial nephrectomy.
  • Radical nephrectomy with immediate renal transplantation: This option is overly invasive for a small tumor and presents additional risks associated with transplantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radical nephrectomy: Leads to loss of renal function in a single kidney patient, necessitating dialysis or transplantation.

 

Option C. Radical nephrectomy with dialysis: An avoidable consequence if the tumor can be effectively treated with partial nephrectomy.

 

Option D. Radical nephrectomy with immediate renal transplantation: Unnecessary for a small, localized tumor and involves higher surgical and postoperative risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a solitary kidney and a small, localized renal tumor (≤4 cm), partial nephrectomy is the preferred management option to preserve renal function and effectively treat the tumor.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma
  2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination
  3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection
  4. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Statements 1, 3 and 4 are true.

 

1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma: This is true. Mammography is an essential tool in the early detection of breast cancer, but it has been associated with over-diagnosis. As a result, some women might receive unnecessary treatment for non-life-threatening tumors.

 

2. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection: This is true. Visual inspection of the oral cavity can detect precancerous lesions or early signs of oral cancer. Regular dental check-ups often include a visual check for signs of oral cancer.

 

3. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear: This is true. A Pap smear (or Pap test) is a procedure to test for cervical cancer in women. The test involves collecting cells from the cervix to be examined under a microscope to detect abnormalities that can turn into cervical cancer.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination: This statement is not entirely accurate. While a digital rectal examination (DRE) can detect some abnormalities or tumors in the rectum, it is not the primary method for colon cancer screening. The primary methods for colon cancer screening include fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, and colonoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates.
  2. Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy.
  3. Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality.
  4. Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test.
  5. Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.

choices.text: Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy

questions.text: In a case of blunt abdominal trauma, a 30-year-old male patient presents with pelvic fracture, minimal urine output on catheterization, and no blood at the meatus. The radiological image shows extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity. What is the preferred next step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparotomy

 

The pattern of contrast extravasation in the given image suggests intraperitoneal bladder rupture, which is caused by a blow or fall on the distended bladder. The preferred next step of management, in this case, is laparotomy for repair and bladder drainage (suprapubic and urethral catheter). Hence, the correct option is C) Laparotomy. Laparoscopic approaches are also now being used.

 

Laparotomy is the preferred next step in management when a patient presents with of extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity (intra-peritoneal rupture), as it may lead to chemical peritonitis. This suggests a significant bladder injury, and a laparotomy is necessary to assess the extent of the injury and provide appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy may be considered in cases of pelvic fracture and suspected urethral rupture. Absence of blood at urethral meatus rules out urethral rupture.

 

Option B. Perurethral catheterization: Perurethral catheterization may not be the best choice in this situation. It is preferred in extra-peritoneal ruptures.

 

Option D. Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy: Pelvic packing and percutaneous nephrostomy may be considered in certain cases of pelvic trauma but are not the primary management options when there is evidence of intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

questions.text: What is shown in the given image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sebaceous cyst

 

The image provided shows a sebaceous cyst, with the characteristic black punctum.

 

  • Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.
  • The most common locations for sebaceous cysts are the face, neck, chest, and back especially postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule.
  • They typically appear as small, painless lumps that are round or oval in shape.
  • Treatment for sebaceous cysts involves surgical removal of the cyst. This is usually done under local anesthesia, and involves making a small elliptical incision in the skin and removing the cyst and its contents.
  • It is important to excise the cyst in its entirety as failure to do so usually results in recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid Cyst:

 

  • A dermoid cyst is a benign, slow-growing cystic lesion that can occur in various parts of the body, including the head and neck.
  • These cysts are often present from birth (congenital) and can contain a variety of tissues, including hair, teeth, and sometimes sebaceous (oil-producing) material.
  • Dermoid cysts are typically painless unless they become infected or inflamed.
  • Treatment involves surgical removal to prevent complications or for cosmetic reasons.

 

Option C. Meningioma:

 

  • A meningioma is a typically benign tumor that originates from the meninges, the membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord.
  • Meningiomas are slow-growing and may not cause symptoms initially.
  • When symptoms occur, they can include headaches, seizures, changes in vision or hearing, and neurological deficits.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed through imaging studies like MRI and CT scans, and treatment may involve surgery or radiation therapy depending on the tumor's location and size.

 

Option D. Postauricular Fistula:

 

  • A postauricular fistula, also known as a auricular sinus or pit, is a small hole or pit located in front of or behind the ear.
  • It is a congenital condition, meaning it is present from birth.
  • These pits can sometimes become infected, leading to symptoms like pain, swelling, and discharge.
  • Surgical removal may be considered if there are recurrent infections or other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial thickness burn? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Papillary dermis

 

The papillary dermis is a layer of the skin that lies just below the epidermis. Blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns occurs within this layer, as it is the point where the burn has affected both the epidermis and the upper portion of the dermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermis: The epidermis is the outermost layer of the skin. In superficial partial thickness burns, this layer is typically damaged, but blister formation occurs slightly deeper within the skin.

 

Option B. Subcutaneous tissue: The subcutaneous tissue is located beneath the dermis and is not typically involved in blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns.

 

Option D. Reticular dermis: The reticular dermis is located deeper in the skin and is not primarily associated with blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns. Blister formation occurs closer to the surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The papillary dermis is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial-thickness burn.

 

First-degree burns involve only the epidermis, with pain, redness, and mild swelling.

 

Second-degree burns involve the epidermis and some parts of the dermis (also known as partial-thickness burns). Further classified as-

 

  • Superficial second degree or superficial partial-thickness burn - involves the upper part of the dermis (papillary) and shows pain, blisters, and severe swelling.
  • Deep second degree or deep partial-thickness burn - extends deeper up to the reticular layer of the dermis and appears paler and more mottled, does not blanch to touch, but remains painful to pinprick.

 

Third-degree or full-thickness burns involve the complete thickness of the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: A fifty-year-old lady presents with a two-year history of recurrent abdominal pain with radiation to her back. The pain is severe in intensity and refractory to simple analgesics. Ultrasound and contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) confirmed the diagnosis and showed a dilated pancreatic duct. Which of the following is the likely recommended surgical procedure of choice: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Longitudinal Pancreatico-Jejunostomy

 

Explanation:

 

Recurrent abdominal pain radiating to the back in a patient with a dilated pancreatic duct, as confirmed by CECT, suggests a diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis. In cases of chronic pancreatitis with a dilated pancreatic duct, a drainage procedure such as longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (also known as Puestow procedure) is the preferred surgical treatment. This procedure involves creating an anastomosis between the pancreatic duct and the jejunum to allow drainage of pancreatic secretions, thereby relieving pain and preventing further damage to the pancreas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vagotomy with antrectomy: This procedure is typically used for peptic ulcer disease and is not indicated for chronic pancreatitis.

 

Option B. Vagotomy with gastrojejunostomy: This combination is also used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease and gastric outlet obstruction but not for chronic pancreatitis with a dilated pancreatic duct.

 

Option C. Whipple’s procedure: Also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, this is a more extensive surgery used primarily for pancreatic head tumors and other periampullary cancers. It is not the first-line treatment for chronic pancreatitis with a dilated duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is the surgical treatment of choice for chronic pancreatitis with a dilated pancreatic duct, as it provides effective drainage and symptomatic relief.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a male patient in his early twenties who presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of abdominal pain and obstipation, and reports blunt injury to the abdomen 3 days prior? The provided X-ray image may provide clues to the diagnosis: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • The given radiograph in the erect position indicates air under the diaphragm, which is a typical finding in cases of hollow viscus perforation.
  • A history of trauma, accompanied by symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation, supports the diagnosis of a perforation of the alimentary tract.

 

A perforation of a hollow organ (like the intestines or stomach) can lead to air and contents of the organ leaking into the abdominal cavity. It can be a result of trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemothorax: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of blood within the pleural cavity, often due to trauma. The patient's symptoms are abdominal in nature and not respiratory, making this an unlikely diagnosis. Hemothorax would be evident on a chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: This is the presence of air in the pleural cavity, often due to trauma or a spontaneous event, leading to lung collapse. Similar to hemothorax, this condition is related to the respiratory system and would not be the cause of abdominal pain or obstipation.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: This condition involves a blockage that prevents the contents of the intestines from passing normally through the digestive tract. However, no free air should be seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation can cause acute bacterial peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum that can be localized or generalized.
  • Clinical features of peritonitis include abdominal pain that worsens with movement, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, and guarding on palpation. Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.
  • An erect abdominal radiograph that shows free gas under the diaphragm.
  • Management of peritonitis involves general care of the patient in terms of nutritional support and pain relief. Laparotomy and surgical treatment of the cause is usually necessary.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of peripheral artery disease presents with symptoms of intermittent claudication and ischemic rest pain in the lower extremities. Further evaluation reveals a significant stenosis in the femoropopliteal artery. The patient is scheduled for a femoropopliteal bypass procedure, and the surgeon must choose the appropriate graft material for the procedure. Which is the best graft for a femoropopliteal bypass?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Great saphenous vein

 

The great saphenous vein, an autologous vein graft, is considered the gold standard for femoropopliteal bypass, especially for below-knee procedures. The great saphenous vein has superior patency rates and fewer complications compared to synthetic grafts in this setting. When available and of good quality, the GSV is the preferred choice for femoropopliteal bypass. The great saphenous vein is the best as it lasts longer than polytetrafluoroethylene, Dacron and human umbilical vein as a graft in a femoropopliteal bypass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dacron: Dacron is a brand name for a type of polyester fiber. It has been used as vascular graft material for several years. Dacron grafts are synthetic and durable, and they are primarily used for larger vessel grafts such as aortoiliac or aortofemoral bypass procedures. However, for femoropopliteal bypass, especially for below-the-knee grafts, Dacron is associated with lower patency rates compared to autologous vein grafts.

 

Option C. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE): Polytetrafluoroethylene (often known by the brand name Teflon) is a synthetic material used as a vascular graft. PTFE grafts are most commonly used when a suitable autologous vein is not available. PTFE has acceptable patency rates, especially for above-the-knee femoropopliteal bypasses. However, for below-the-knee grafts, the GSV usually outperforms PTFE in terms of long-term patency.

 

Option D. Short Saphenous Vein: The short saphenous vein runs along the back of the calf and drains into the popliteal vein. While it can be used as a graft for femoropopliteal bypass, it is not as commonly chosen as the great saphenous vein. The GSV is generally longer, more superficial, and easier to harvest, making it the preferred autologous graft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great saphenous vein is the preferred graft material for femoropopliteal bypass due to its superior patency rates and longevity compared to synthetic grafts like Dacron or polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE).

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompression

 

The patient presents with signs of an acute epidural hematoma (EDH), as evidenced by the biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on the CT scan, along with a deteriorating Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10/15. An epidural hematoma is a neurosurgical emergency, especially when accompanied by neuro deterioration, as in this case. The immediate next step is decompression, which involves relieving the pressure on the brain by surgically removing the hematoma. This procedure can be done through a burr hole or craniotomy and is crucial to prevent further brain injury or death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Mannitol: Although IV mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure, it is not the definitive treatment for an acute EDH with neuro deterioration. Mannitol may be used temporarily to manage intracranial pressure, but it does not address the underlying cause of the pressure, which is the hematoma.

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This approach is inappropriate in this scenario due to the immediate threat posed by the hematoma. Delaying treatment could lead to irreversible brain damage or death.

 

Option D. Anticoagulation: Administering anticoagulation would exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient’s condition. It is contraindicated in the setting of an active intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural hematoma with neuro deterioration is a neurosurgical emergency that requires immediate decompression to prevent further brain injury and improve patient outcomes.

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.text: A female patient presents to the clinic with a painful lump in her breast that has been increasing in size over the past few days. After examination, the doctor diagnoses her with a breast abscess and prescribes antibiotics to help clear the infection. The doctor attempts to aspirate the abscess using a needle and syringe, but no fluid is obtained. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A second attempt at aspiration

 

Explanation:

 

If the first attempt at aspiration fails to obtain fluid, the next logical step is to attempt aspiration again, potentially with ultrasound guidance. Ultrasound guidance can enhance the accuracy of the procedure by allowing direct visualization of the abscess, ensuring that the needle is correctly positioned to access the abscess cavity. This method is less invasive than incision and drainage (I&D), making it a preferred option if it can effectively manage the abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and Drainage: Incision and drainage is generally considered if aspiration fails repeatedly or if the abscess is too large. While effective, it is not typically the immediate next step after a single failed aspiration attempt. It is more invasive than aspiration and usually reserved for cases where less invasive methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option B. Continue antibiotics only: Antibiotics are crucial in managing breast abscesses by treating the underlying infection. However, they alone might not suffice for large or dense abscesses. The pus trapped within the abscess often needs to be physically removed to expedite healing and provide symptom relief. Continuing antibiotics without addressing the abscess can lead to prolonged infection and discomfort.

 

Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected: This option is not recommended. The failure to collect aspirate does not imply the absence of infection. The antibiotics were prescribed based on the clinical diagnosis of a breast abscess, and stopping them prematurely could allow the infection to worsen. Continuation of antibiotics is important until the course is complete or unless indicated otherwise by a physician.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the initial aspiration attempt for a breast abscess fails, the next step should be to attempt aspiration again, preferably under ultrasound guidance, before considering more invasive procedures like incision and drainage. This approach ensures accurate access to the abscess and minimizes invasiveness.

choices.text: First Angiography to confirm the diagnosis

questions.text: A patient presented with red, tender, pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region. Which of the following is more appropriately done in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First Angiography to confirm the diagnosis

 

The patient presents with a red, tender, pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region. The term "pulsatile" suggests that the swelling has a vascular origin, likely an aneurysm or other vascular abnormality. The primary goal in managing such a swelling is to correctly identify its nature, which necessitates imaging.

 

Angiography is an imaging modality that visualizes blood vessels, helping to confirm whether the swelling is vascular, such as an aneurysm or pseudoaneurysm. This step is critical because if the swelling is indeed vascular, inappropriate interventions like incision and drainage could lead to severe complications, including hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. First antibiotics and observation: This approach might be considered for a non-pulsatile infectious swelling, but given the vascular nature indicated by the pulsatile quality, antibiotics alone would not address the underlying vascular issue.

 

Option C. Incision and drainage: This procedure is appropriate for abscesses or other non-vascular swellings. Performing an incision and drainage on a vascular swelling can result in catastrophic bleeding.

 

Option D. Surgical Excision: While this might eventually be necessary, it should only be considered after confirming the diagnosis with appropriate imaging to plan the surgery safely. Blindly excising a vascular swelling without proper diagnosis can be very dangerous.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region, indicative of a vascular abnormality, angiography is essential to confirm the diagnosis before deciding on the appropriate intervention.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixter forceps

 

Mixter forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss and pass ligatures and dissect pedicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adson's forceps: Adson's forceps are used in surgery to manipulate soft tissues such as fascia and skin during suturing.

 

 

Option B. Kocher's forceps: Kocher's forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss. It has 2 x 1 teeth at the tip.

 

 

Option D. Rampley forceps: Rampley forceps are used in general surgery to hold swabs and sponges or to grasp tissue. It has a fenestrated tip.

choices.text: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with pain and swelling in the left side of his scrotum. The surgeon suspects testicular torsion based on the clinical presentation. Which is the most appropriate next step in management? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side

 

In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side.

 

  • This is the most appropriate next step in management for suspected testicular torsion. It involves immediate surgical exploration of both the symptomatic (painful) side and the asymptomatic (contralateral) side. Even if only one side appears to be affected, there is a risk of contralateral testicular torsion in future. This occurs as the same anatomical abnormality (high investment of tunica vaginalis/transverse testis are likely to be present on both sides.
  • The surgeon can detorse (untwist) the affected testicle and fixate it to prevent future torsion. Contralateral scrotum is explored and orchidopexy is done to prevent future risk of torsion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of testicular torsion: 

 

  • Timely diagnosis: Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency and requires prompt diagnosis and management to salvage the testis as the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis.
  • Surgery: The definitive management of testicular torsion is surgical exploration with detorsion and fixation of the testis to prevent future torsion. The surgery should be performed within 6 hours of the onset of symptoms to maximize the chances of testicular salvage. At the time of surgical exploration contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed as the same anatomic defect can allow torsion on the contralateral side.

choices.text: Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain
Oscillation of water column in the tube

questions.text: Proper functioning of an ICD tube is checked by: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oscillation of water column in the tube

 

Functioning of the ICD tube can be confirmed by seeing the column of water in the chest tube oscillate up and down during respiration.

 

The oscillation or fluctuation of the water column in the water seal chamber of an ICD tube is a key indicator of proper functioning. This movement indicates that there is a patent (open) airway between the pleural space and the water seal, allowing air and fluid to exit the pleural cavity and preventing air from re-entering during inhalation. It's a visual confirmation that the ICD is effectively draining the pleural space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain: While air bubbles can sometimes be seen in the water seal chamber of an ICD system, their presence does not necessarily indicate proper functioning.

 

Option C. Chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable information about the position and placement of the ICD tube, it is not typically used as the primary method for checking its ongoing functioning. X-rays are often performed initially after tube insertion to confirm placement.

 

Option D. Auscultation: Auscultation can help assess lung sounds and detect any abnormalities, but it may not be the most direct method for checking the functioning of an ICD tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

An intercostal drainage (ICD) tube is a thin, plastic tube that's inserted into the pleural space. The pleural space is the area between the chest wall and the lungs. 

 

The ICD tube is used to drain abnormal collections in the pleural cavity. It helps remove: Air (pneumothorax), Blood (hemothorax), Fluid (pleural effusion or hydrothorax, Chyle (chylothorax, Purulence (empyema. 

 

The ICD tube creates negative pressure in the chest cavity, which allows the lung to re-expand.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of heavy alcohol use presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back and recurrent vomiting. On examination, the patient has tenderness and guarding in the upper epigastrium. The chest x-ray is normal. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum Lipase

 

Serum lipase is an enzyme produced by the pancreas. Elevated levels of serum lipase are a hallmark of acute pancreatitis. It is a critical diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis in a patient with symptoms suggestive of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Upper GI endoscopy is used to visualize the upper gastrointestinal tract, which may help diagnose conditions like peptic ulcers or esophagitis. However, in this case, the symptoms and clinical findings are more indicative of acute pancreatitis rather than upper GI issues.

 

Option B. Alcohol breath test: An alcohol breath test is used to detect recent alcohol consumption. While the patient has a history of heavy alcohol use, this test won't provide information about the current medical condition, such as pancreatitis.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): A contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) can be a valuable tool for confirming the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis and assessing its severity. However, in many cases, a serum lipase test is ordered first because it's a quicker and less invasive way to diagnose acute pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abdominal pain with recurrent vomiting in a chronic alcoholic with upper epigastric guarding is highly suggestive of pancreatitis.
  • A normal erect chest x-ray suggests that there is no pneumoperitoneum, effectively ruling out perforation.
  • In this setting, the main differential diagnosis to consider is pancreatitis.
  • The next appropriate investigation would be a serum lipase test to confirm the diagnosis of pancreatitis.

choices.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG
Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.text: 50-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The physician suspects acute cholecystitis and orders imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is not true about acute cholecystitis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan.

 

This statement is not true. In a Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid (HIDA) scan, the gallbladder is not preferentially visualized in acute cholecystitis. Instead, one of the hallmark findings in acute cholecystitis on a HIDA scan is non-visualization of the gallbladder due to inflammation and obstruction of the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG: This statement is true and is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. On ultrasound (USG), a thickened gallbladder wall, typically greater than 3 mm, is indicative of inflammation and is a characteristic feature of acute cholecystitis.

 

Option B. Murphy's sign positive: This statement is true. Murphy's sign is a clinical maneuver used to assess for acute cholecystitis. It involves palpation of the right upper quadrant during inspiration, and if the patient experiences pain or stops breathing due to pain during this maneuver, it is considered a positive Murphy's sign, suggesting inflammation of the gallbladder.

 

Option C. Leukocytosis: This statement is true. Acute cholecystitis is associated with an inflammatory response, leading to an elevation in white blood cell count, which is known as leukocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute cholecystitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to the presence of gallstones obstructing the cystic duct. Clinical features of acute cholecystitis include right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. A positive Murphy's sign is right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. On ultrasound imaging, gall bladder thickness >3 mm is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. The HIDA scan is a diagnostic tool for acute cholecystitis, showing non-visualization of the gall bladder 3 hours after radioisotope administration. Preferential visualization of the gall bladder on a HIDA scan is not a feature of acute cholecystitis. It is important to diagnose and treat acute cholecystitis promptly to prevent complications such as gallbladder perforation or gangrene.

choices.text: Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

questions.text: A 25-year-old male individual arrived at the emergency room following a road traffic accident, displaying signs indicative of a potential pelvic fracture. Upon assessment, he was determined to be experiencing hypovolemic shock. What is the initial course of action for managing hemorrhage control in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

 

In the immediate aftermath of a traumatic injury where a pelvic fracture is suspected, binding the pelvis with sheets (or commercial binders, if available) is a quick and effective way to provide temporary stabilization and reduce ongoing bleeding. This technique uses the concept of tamponading or compressing the bleeding vessels within the pelvis, which can be life-saving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate internal fixation: This involves surgical stabilization of the pelvic fracture. While internal fixation might ultimately be necessary, it's not the initial action. Operating on an unstable patient can lead to further complications.

 

Option B. Multiple blood transfusions: Transfusing blood is critical for a patient in hypovolemic shock due to bleeding. However, it addresses the consequence (loss of blood) rather than the cause (active bleeding from the fracture). Stopping or controlling the bleed is paramount.

 

Option D. Emergency external fixation: External fixators can be applied to stabilize the pelvis and control hemorrhage. While this is a more definitive action than using bedsheets, it requires more time, equipment, and a surgical setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the acute nature of the presentation and the need for immediate action to address life-threatening bleeding, the primary and fastest step would be C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis. This is a temporizing measure that can stabilize the patient until more definitive interventions (like external or internal fixation) can be safely undertaken.

questions.text: In a Preoperative surgical safety Checklist, which of the following is not a component? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Signature of the doctor

 

In a preoperative patient surgical safety checklist, doctor's signature is not needed.

 

the signature of the doctor, is not typically a component of the surgical safety checklist. Instead, the checklist focuses on verifying critical safety elements like patient consent, equipment functionality, and instrument sterility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Consent: Ensuring that informed consent has been obtained from the patient is a crucial component of preoperative safety checklists. It confirms that the patient has been informed about the procedure, risks, and alternatives and has given their consent for the surgery.

 

Option C. Functioning pulse oximeter: Checking the functioning of medical equipment like a pulse oximeter is an important step in preoperative safety. It ensures that necessary monitoring devices are in working order to monitor the patient's vital signs during surgery.

 

Option D. Sterility of instruments: Verifying the sterility of surgical instruments is essential to prevent infections during surgery. It ensures that all instruments that will come into contact with the patient are properly sterilized and safe for use.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Hepatic avulsions are classified as what grade according to the AAST liver injury scale? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grade V 

 

Explanation:

 

Hepatic avulsions are classified as Grade V in the AAST liver injury scale. This represents the highest grade of liver injury, reflecting complete detachment of the liver or severe damage to major vascular pedicles. The AAST grading system categorizes liver injuries progressively from minor lacerations to complete avulsion, with Grade V being the most severe form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade I - Incorrect Grade I liver injuries only involve minor lacerations less than 1cm in depth. These are superficial injuries that don't involve vascular structures and typically heal without surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Grade II - Incorrect Grade II liver injuries involve lacerations between 1-3cm in depth but don't involve major vascular structures. These moderate injuries are far less severe than complete avulsions.

 

Option C. Grade IV - Incorrect Grade IV liver injuries involve parenchymal disruption affecting 25-75% of one hepatic lobe. While serious, these don't constitute complete avulsion of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic avulsion represents the most severe form of liver trauma in the AAST classification system and is designated as Grade V. Management of such injuries typically requires damage control surgery with the "4 Ps" approach: Push, Pack, Plug, and Pringle maneuver.

questions.text: Which of the following structures forms the lateral boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior epigastric vessels 

 

Hesselbach's triangle, also known as the inguinal triangle, is an anatomical area of the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

These vessels form the lateral border of the triangle. They run superomedially towards the umbilicus from the external iliac vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectus abdominis muscle: This is the medial border of Hesselbach's triangle.

 

Option B. Inguinal ligament: This forms the base or inferior border of the triangle. It is a band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine.

 

Option D. Conjoint tendon: Also known as the inguinal aponeurotic falx, this is not a border of Hesselbach's triangle but is located just medial to the triangle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The inferior epigastric vessels form the lateral boundary of Hesselbach's triangle, which is an area of the abdominal wall clinically significant in the diagnosis of direct inguinal hernias.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the ER with a history of trauma two weeks back with confusion and ataxia. CT scan reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural haemorrhage

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).
  • Subdural hematomas typically occur due to the rupture of bridging veins, which can be associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, or chronic alcohol overuse.
  •  The presentation of symptoms like confusion and ataxia two weeks after trauma is characteristic of a chronic subdural hematoma.

 

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of bridging veins.
  • Etiology: Can be acute (traumatic) or chronic (associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, chronic alcohol overuse). Also seen in shaken babies.
  • Clinical Features: Typically presents without a lucid interval; altered consciousness from the onset. Features of raised intracranial tension and neurological deficits may be present.
  • CT Findings: Crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (branch of the maxillary artery), often secondary to a skull fracture involving the pterion.
  • Clinical Features: Often includes a lucid interval (period of normalcy between two periods of unconsciousness).
  • CT Findings: Biconvex (lentiform), hyperdense blood collection that does not cross suture lines.

 

Option C. Intra-parenchymal Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Most commonly caused by systemic hypertension.
  • Location: Most often occurs in the putamen/globus pallidus of the basal ganglia (lenticulostriate vessels).
  • CT Findings: Intra-parenchymal bleed.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Bleeding due to trauma or rupture of an aneurysm (such as a saccular aneurysm).
  • Clinical Features: Patients complain of the “worst headache of my life.” Bloody or yellow lumbar puncture. Vasospasm can occur, nimodipine is used to prevent/reduce it.
  • CT Findings: Intraventricular and subarachnoid space hyperdensities represent acute hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subdural hematoma typically results from the rupture of bridging veins and presents without a lucid interval.
  •  CT scans of subdural hematoma show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

choices.text: 2-3 hours after a hyperosmolar meal

questions.text: All of the following are true about Delayed or Late Dumping Syndrome, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diarrhea

 

Explanation:

 

Late dumping syndrome is a consequence of peptic ulcer surgery characterized by reactive hypoglycemia occurring typically 1-3 hours after meals. It develops when carbohydrate-rich food causes a rapid rise in blood glucose, triggering an excessive insulin response that leads to subsequent hypoglycemia. Diarrhea is typical of early dumping.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2-3 hours after hyperosmolar meal - TRUE for late dumping. Late dumping occurs in the second hour after meals, typically 1-3 hours post-meal. The timing is correct.

 

Option B. Reactive hypoglycemia - TRUE for late dumping. Late dumping is defined as reactive hypoglycemia caused by the carbohydrate load in the small bowel, leading to a rise in plasma glucose, which triggers insulin release and subsequent hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Neuroglucopenic symptoms are prominent - TRUE for late dumping. The symptoms of late dumping include tremor, faintness, prostration, dizziness, and palpitations, which are manifestations of hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Late dumping syndrome presents 1-3 hours after meals with hypoglycemic symptoms (tremors, faintness, dizziness) due to reactive hypoglycemia, while diarrhea is characteristic of early dumping syndrome which occurs immediately after meals.

 

 

Features of Early and Late Dumping

questions.text: Match the surgery with related nerve injuries: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

 

The following are the associations between the type of surgery and the nerve most commonly at risk of injury:

 

A. Breast surgery - Long Thoracic Nerve: The Long Thoracic Nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which anchors the scapula to the chest wall. Injury to this nerve during breast surgery, especially radical mastectomies where axillary lymph nodes are removed, can lead to a condition called "winged scapula," where the medial border of the scapula protrudes outwards.

 

B. Thyroid surgery - External Laryngeal nerve: The External Laryngeal nerve is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (itself a branch of the vagus nerve). It supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which plays a role in tensioning the vocal cords. Injury during thyroid surgery can lead to voice changes, particularly affecting the pitch.

 

C. Submandibular excision - Hypoglossal nerve: The Hypoglossal nerve is the twelfth cranial nerve and supplies the muscles of the tongue. Injury to this nerve during excision of the submandibular gland can lead to tongue deviation towards the side of the injury due to the unopposed action of the tongue muscles on the unaffected side.

 

D. Thymectomy - Vagus nerve: The Vagus nerve, or the tenth cranial nerve, has a wide range of functions including supplying parasympathetic fibers to many organs in the thorax and abdomen. Injury during thymectomy, a surgical procedure to can have multiple effects, including voice changes due to its role in innervating the larynx. However, it's worth noting that the phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, is also at risk during a thymectomy.

 

In summary, during surgical procedures, it's imperative to be aware of the nearby nerves and their courses to prevent unintended nerve injury, as this can lead to significant postoperative complications

questions.text: What is the management for a patient with a road traffic accident who presents with hemothorax, evidenced by 1800 ml of blood loss via a chest tube in 1 hour? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thoracotomy

 

A patient presenting with hemothorax after a road traffic accident and an output of 1800 ml of blood via a chest tube within 1 hour indicates significant ongoing bleeding, likely from a major arterial source. This situation requires immediate surgical intervention.

 

Thoracotomy is the appropriate management in this case. The procedure involves opening the thoracic cavity to directly visualize and control the bleeding source, which is crucial to prevent further blood loss and stabilize the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent thoracocentesis: This is incorrect because thoracocentesis is used for diagnostic drainage of pleural fluid, but it is not appropriate when there is already a chest tube in place showing significant ongoing bleeding.

 

Option C. Drain for next 6 hours: This is incorrect as continuing to drain without addressing the source of the bleeding will not resolve the ongoing hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: This is incorrect as this approach is suitable only if the initial output is less than 1500 ml or if the output is less than 250 ml per hour over three consecutive hours. The given scenario exceeds these parameters, indicating the need for immediate surgical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with hemothorax and significant ongoing blood loss via a chest tube, immediate thoracotomy is indicated to control the source of bleeding and stabilize the patient.

questions.text: A patient with history of alcoholism presented with right hypochondriac pain and fever. He had an episode of diarrhoea 1 week prior. USG abdomen reveals a liver abscess of around 25 cc in right lobe. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medical management

 

  • This patient with USG revealing abscess in the liver most likely has an amebic liver abscess. Since next best is asked, medical management should be started first.

 

Amoebic liver abscess:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PAIR: PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration) is more commonly used for hydatid cysts and not the first-line treatment for amoebic liver abscesses.

 

Option B. Surgery: Surgical intervention is generally reserved for cases where there is no response to medical treatment or complications arise.

 

Option D. Percutaneous drainage: This can be considered if the abscess is large, at risk of rupture, or if there is no response to medical management. However, initial treatment should be medical management with antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For amoebic liver abscess, initial management should always begin with medical therapy using metronidazole, chloroquine, and diloxanide furoate.
  •  Drainage or aspiration is considered based on the size and risk of rupture of the abscess.

choices.text: Visible peristalsis from left to right

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following will not be seen in this child? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilious vomiting

 

In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pylorus muscle lead to gastric outlet obstruction. This causes projectile, non-bilious vomiting because the obstruction is proximal to the bile duct entry into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Visible peristalsis from left to right: Due to the obstruction caused by CHPS, there's an increase in gastric peristalsis as the stomach tries to push its contents past the hypertrophied pylorus. This can result in visible waves of peristalsis moving from the left side of the abdomen (where the stomach is located) to the right side (towards the pylorus) on giving a feed.

 

Option C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia: Persistent vomiting in CHPS can lead to the loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid). This results in hypochloremia due to the loss of chloride ions. The body also tries to compensate for the alkalosis by excreting more potassium in the kidneys, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: As mentioned earlier, the loss of gastric acid from repeated vomiting results in a state of metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age.
  • It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS.
  • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS.
  • A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting.
  • The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia).
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria.
  • Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with anorexia, nausea, vomiting and epigastric pain radiating towards the back. On investigation, Serum amylase is 1400; all other lab parameters are normal, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Pancreatitis

 

The patient's presentation and laboratory findings are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Key symptoms and findings supporting this diagnosis include:

 

  • Epigastric pain radiating to the back: This is a classic symptom of acute pancreatitis. The pain is typically severe, constant, and often relieved by leaning forward.
  • Nausea and vomiting: These are common symptoms associated with acute pancreatitis.
  • Elevated serum amylase: A serum amylase level of 1400 U/L is significantly elevated, which is a hallmark of acute pancreatitis. Amylase levels typically rise within 6-12 hours of onset and can remain elevated for several days.

 

Signs and Symptoms of Acute Pancreatitis:

 

  • Pain: Acute onset of severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back.
  • Nausea and vomiting: Common accompanying symptoms.
  • Physical signs: May include hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea.
  • Characteristic discoloration:
    • Grey Turner's sign: Bluish discoloration of the flanks.
    • Cullen's sign: Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus.
    • Fox's sign: Discoloration below the inguinal ligament.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Cholecystitis:

 

  • Symptoms: Right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and food aversion. Pain does not typically radiate to the back as in pancreatitis.
  • Serum Amylase: Usually not significantly elevated in acute cholecystitis.

 

Option C. Acute Appendicitis:

 

  • Symptoms: Periumbilical pain that later shifts to the right lower quadrant (McBurney's point). Pain typically does not radiate to the back.
  • Serum Amylase: Not elevated in acute appendicitis.

 

Option D. Chronic Hepatitis:

 

  • Symptoms: May include fatigue, jaundice, anorexia, and abdominal discomfort, but not typically severe epigastric pain radiating to the back.
  • Serum Amylase: Not elevated in chronic hepatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute pancreatitis should be suspected in a patient with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, especially with significantly elevated serum amylase levels.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a long-standing history of recurrent abdominal pain, nausea, and steatorrhea. The patient reports a significant history of alcohol abuse, and diagnostic imaging reveals signs of chronic pancreatitis. What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alcohol

 

Chronic alcohol consumption is the leading cause of chronic pancreatitis. Excessive alcohol intake can lead to repeated episodes of acute pancreatitis, eventually resulting in chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of pancreatic function. Alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis often presents with pain, malabsorption (leading to steatorrhea), and diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of insulin-producing cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gallstones: When they travel out of the gallbladder into the bile ducts, they can block the pancreatic duct, leading to inflammation of the pancreas, termed acute pancreatitis. While gallstones are a common cause of acute pancreatitis, they are not the predominant cause of chronic pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Autoimmune: Autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) is a type of chronic pancreatitis caused by an autoimmune reaction against the pancreatic tissue. It can be part of the spectrum of IgG4-related disease. The pancreas may become enlarged and look like a tumor on imaging studies. AIP might present with jaundice, weight loss, and the aforementioned pancreatic enlargement. Treatment usually involves corticosteroids to suppress the immune response.

 

Option D. Drugs: Some drugs are known to cause pancreatitis. While the incidence is generally low, drug-induced pancreatitis can turn chronic if the offending medication isn't identified and discontinued. Common culprits include diuretics like furosemide and thiazides, certain antiretroviral drugs, and some antiepileptics like valproic acid, among others.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcohol consumption is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis, leading to repeated inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of pancreatic function over time.

questions.text: In a patient at risk of re-feeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia 

 

Unlike hypokalemia, hyperkalemia is not typically associated with re-feeding syndrome. Instead, rapid re-feeding may lead to increased insulin secretion, which drives potassium into cells, potentially causing hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: Re-feeding syndrome can lead to hypokalemia due to increased cellular uptake of potassium during the anabolic phase, especially if there is concomitant insulin administration.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Re-feeding syndrome can cause hypocalcemia due to decreased parathyroid hormone secretion and subsequent impaired bone resorption, leading to low serum calcium levels.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemia: Re-feeding syndrome is characterized by rapid shifts of phosphate into cells during the anabolic phase, leading to hypophosphatemia, which can manifest clinically as weakness, respiratory failure, and arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In patients at risk of re-feeding syndrome, electrolyte imbalances such as hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia are commonly observed, while hyperkalemia is typically not associated with this condition.

choices.text: Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region
Brilliant transillumination when a light is shone through the mass
Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line
Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed
