questions.text: Identify the true statement about the Tillaux sign? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mobility of the mass perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line

 

Tillaux sign is seen in presence of mesenteric cyst, which shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment.

 

The Tillaux sign refers to the observation that a tumor arising from mesentry, typically a mesenteric cyst will move in a direction perpendicular to the line of mesenteric attachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of a mass in the periumbilical region: While the presence of a mass can be indicative of many conditions, the Tillaux sign specifically refers to the mobility of a mass in relation to the mesentery attachment, not merely the presence of a mass.

 

Option B. Brilliance of transillumination when a light is shone through the mass: This describes the positive transillumination test that might be observed in cystic masses like hydroceles or  superficial cysts with clear fluid like ranula.

 

Option D. Positive fluctuation observed when the mass is pressed: This refers to a fluctuation test, where pressing on one side of a fluid-filled mass results in a palpable bulge or movement on the opposite side. This indicates the presence of fluid within the mass but isn't related to the Tillaux sign.

 

In summary, the Tillaux sign helps in the clinical assessment of abdominal masses, with the mass's mobility providing clues about its origin and location in relation to the mesentery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tillaux's sign is positive when a mesenteric cyst is present, and the mass or swelling is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line. Mesenteric cysts are typically found in the small intestine (60%) or colon (40%) and can be classified as chylolymphatic (the most common type), enterogenous, urogenital remnant, or dermoid. These cysts are commonly found in adults and are characterized by a painless abdominal swelling with physical signs (Tillaux triad) such as a fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus, a mass that moves freely in a plane perpendicular to the attachment of the mesentery (known as Tillaux's sign), and the presence of a zone of resonance around the cyst.

 

Tillaux triad of mesenteric cyst:

 

  1. Soft fluctuant periumbilical lump
  2. Movement perpendicular to mesenteric attachment
  3. Zone of resonance around the lump

choices.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
Day to day distance is variable
Relived after getting out of bed

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker is diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease. Identify the true statement about intermittent claudication: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most commonly felt in the calf muscles

 

Most commonly felt in the calf muscles: Correct. Intermittent claudication most commonly affects the calf muscles because the disease often affects the arteries supplying the lower limbs, usually the superficial femoral artery (70% of cases). Patients describe it as a cramping or aching sensation that occurs with walking or exertion and is relieved with rest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Felt at rest: Incorrect. Intermittent claudication is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest. It occurs due to inadequate blood flow to the muscles during exertion.

 

Option C. Day to day distance is variable: Incorrect. While the severity of peripheral artery disease can change over time (especially without treatment), typically, the distance a person can walk before symptoms begin is fairly consistent, especially in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. Relieved after getting out of bed: Incorrect. Intermittent claudication pain is typically relieved after a few minutes of rest and doesn't specifically correlate with getting out of bed. The pain usually occurs during physical activities, such as walking, and subsides with rest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles due to the high prevalence of peripheral artery disease affecting the arteries that supply the lower limbs. This condition is typically brought on by physical activity and relieved by rest.

questions.text: A child presented with bilious vomiting. What will be the most appropriate test to diagnose the condition in this baby? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CECT abdomen

 

Bilious vomiting in a child suggests an obstruction distal to the second part of the duodenum. The appropriate diagnostic test should provide a comprehensive view of the entire abdominal region to pinpoint the site of obstruction or other causes.

 

CECT abdomen (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen):

 

  • Relevance: A CECT abdomen provides a detailed study of the entire abdominal region, helping to pinpoint the site of obstruction or other causes of bilious vomiting. It offers a comprehensive view of both the gastrointestinal tract and surrounding structures, making it the most appropriate test in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barium swallow:

 

  • Description: A barium swallow is used to evaluate the structure of the esophagus by having the patient swallow a barium sulfate drink and then taking X-ray images.
  • Relevance: This test is appropriate for assessing abnormalities in the esophagus such as strictures or tumors but is not typically used for diagnosing conditions that result in bilious vomiting in children.

 

Option B. Barium meal:

 

  • Description: A barium meal evaluates the structure and function of the stomach and the proximal part of the small intestine.
  • Relevance: While it can visualize the stomach and the beginning of the small intestine, it might not provide a full picture of a distal obstruction or other causes of bilious vomiting.

 

Option C. Barium meal follow through:

 

  • Description: This test involves swallowing barium sulfate and then taking X-ray images at intervals as the barium moves through the entire small intestine.
  • Relevance: It allows visualization of the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. This would be more comprehensive than a simple barium meal for identifying sites of obstruction or other abnormalities in the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For diagnosing bilious vomiting in a child, a CECT abdomen is the most appropriate test as it provides a comprehensive view of the entire abdominal region, helping to pinpoint the site of obstruction or other causes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, and signs of dehydration. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness, and urine analysis indicates sterile pyuria. An image is provided. What is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Putty kidney

 

  • The given image finding of a putty kidney is suggestive of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB).
  • Putty kidney is characterized by a homogenous and ground glass-like calcification of the kidney.
  • Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria and is always a secondary TB caused by dissemination through the bloodstream.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by a tuberculin test or acid-fast bacilli staining and culture of urine samples.
  • CT urography is the preferred imaging modality for visualizing renal calcifications and assessing the various stages of renal TB.
  • Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs and surgical intervention may be necessary, such as partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrocalcinosis: Is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Staghorncalculus: Kidney stones are a type of large urinary calculus that takes up a large portion of the urinary collecting area in the kidney. They often present in only one kidney, but in up to 15% of cases, they form in both. They often form due to recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

Option D. Psoas calcification: Refers to the calcification (formation of calcium deposits) in the psoas muscle, which is a large muscle in the lower back that plays a role in hip flexion and trunk stabilization. Psoas calcification is not directly related to kidney or urinary system conditions and may have other underlying causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Putty kidney is a radiographic finding associated with genitourinary tuberculosis, characterized by homogenous, ground glass-like calcifications in the kidney.
  •  This condition typically presents with symptoms such as sterile pyuria, and diagnosis is confirmed through specific TB testing and imaging modalities like CT urography.
  •  Treatment usually involves antitubercular drugs and may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining multiple injuries in a motor vehicle accident. The patient is hemodynamically unstable and requires a massive blood transfusion. The physician is concerned about the potential adverse effects of the transfusion and wants to monitor the patient closely. The physician wants to confirm which of the following adverse effects is not commonly observed in patients who receive a massive blood transfusion? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia

 

This is not a common adverse effect of blood transfusions. Blood transfusions are more likely to cause hypocalcemia due to citrate binding calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypocalcemia: It can occur after a massive blood transfusion because citrate, an anticoagulant used in blood storage bags, can bind to calcium, reducing its levels when the transfused blood is administered. Citrate is used to prevent blood clotting during storage but can have this effect when transfused.

 

Option C. Hypokalemia: It can rarely occur after a massive blood transfusion because of dilution of recipient’s blood potassium.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: This is a potential adverse effect of a massive blood transfusion. Stored blood cells can undergo lysis leading to higher potassium levels in the blood products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypocalcemia and not Hypercalcemia is an adverse effect of massive blood transfusion.
  • Massive blood transfusion instead leads to Hypocalcemia as the anticoagulant citrate binds to calcium.

 

The complications of massive blood transfusion are:

 

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypothermia
  • Alkalosis

choices.text: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient arrives at the emergency department with a history of stabbing injury to her arm. Upon examination, there is a noticeable hematoma, and the patient reports not feeling any radial or ulnar pulses in the affected arm. Imaging reveals a 3cm longitudinal tear in the brachial artery. The medical team is faced with deciding the best treatment option for the patient. Which option should they choose? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repair with great saphenous vein graft

 

  • The preferred treatment option for a patient with an injury to the brachial artery caused by a stab injury is to repair it with a great saphenous vein graft harvested from the patient's uninjured leg.
  • Repairing vessel injuries requires a tension-free approach.
  • The great saphenous vein is the most desirable graft for interposition grafts because of its elastic properties, similar diameter to that of an extremity artery, lack of thrombogenicity, and long-term patency.
  • Other graft materials that can be used include the cephalic vein, lesser saphenous vein, and prosthetic conduits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis: Primary arterial repair with end-to-end anastomosis is only possible if the repair can be performed in a tension-free manner. If the injured area is too long, an interposition graft is required.

 

Option C. Repair with prosthetic graft: Prosthetic grafts are only preferred when the native saphenous vein has been traumatized or when there is a size mismatch. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) graft is commonly used as a prosthetic conduit.

 

Option D. Repair with saphenous vein patch: Saphenous vein patch is used for the closure of arteriotomy site during carotid endarterectomies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Repair with a great saphenous vein graft is an appropriate choice in cases of brachial artery injury with extensive damage and vascular compromise, allowing for the restoration of blood flow to the arm. This surgical intervention should be performed urgently to prevent further ischemic complications in the affected limb.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and jaundice. Upon evaluation, an ultrasound of the abdomen was performed. Based on the image provided, which structure likely represents a choledochal cyst? Identify the choledochal cyst in the image below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type III

 

The image depicts a choledochocele, which is a Type III choledochal cyst. Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the biliary ducts and are more common in females. These cysts can lead to recurrent abdominal pain and jaundice due to bile duct obstruction.

 

  • Type I (MC): Dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree.
    • Type Ia: Cystic dilation (most common type).
    • Type Ib: Focal segmental dilation.
    • Type Ic: Fusiform dilation.
  • Type II: Diverticular dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree.
  • Type III: Cystic dilation of the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct, known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: Dilation of both the extrahepatic and intrahepatic biliary tree.
  • Type IVB: Dilation of multiple sections of the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V: Dilation confined to the intrahepatic bile ducts, also known as Caroli’s disease.
  • Type VI: Cystic dilation of the cystic duct (not included in Todani’s modification).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: Represents dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree. It is the most common type but does not correspond to the image provided.

 

Option C. Type IV: Involves dilation of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. The image does not show such extensive dilation.

 

Option D. Type V: Known as Caroli's disease, involves dilation confined to the intrahepatic bile ducts, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Choledochal cysts are classified into several types based on the location and nature of the biliary dilation. Type III choledochal cysts, or choledochocele, involve cystic dilation of the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency room with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following interventions is not typically performed in this situation? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelet transfusion

 

  • Platelet transfusion is not typically performed as an immediate intervention for variceal bleeding. Platelets are responsible for blood clotting, but variceal bleeding is primarily caused by the rupture of dilated blood vessels (varices) in the esophagus or stomach, which is related to portal hypertension.
  • Platelet transfusions are usually considered when a patient with liver cirrhosis has significant thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) or when there is an underlying bleeding disorder. However, they are not the primary treatment for variceal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arrange PRBC (packed red blood cell) transfusion: PRBC transfusion is often necessary to replace lost blood and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status. Active variceal bleeding can lead to significant blood loss, and transfusion of red blood cells is a crucial part of resuscitation.

 

Option C. IV Octreotide: IV Octreotide is commonly administered in cases of active variceal bleeding. Octreotide is a medication that helps reduce portal pressure by constricting blood vessels, including those in the varices. This can help control the bleeding until more definitive treatment, such as endoscopy or interventional radiology procedures, can be performed.

 

Option D. Urgent Endoscopy: Urgent endoscopy, typically performed within 12-24 hours, is a critical intervention in the management of variceal bleeding. During endoscopy, a gastroenterologist can identify the source of bleeding and perform interventions such as band ligation or sclerotherapy to stop the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of variceal bleeding:

 

  • Initial resuscitation: The first step in the management of variceal bleeding is to stabilize the patient with aggressive resuscitation measures, including airway management, fluid and blood product resuscitation, and correction of coagulopathy.
  • Endoscopy: Early endoscopy allows for the identification of the bleeding site and the application of endoscopic therapies such as band ligation or sclerotherapy.
  • Pharmacological therapy: Vasopressin and its analogs (such as terlipressin) are commonly used in the management of variceal bleeding to decrease portal pressure and reduce the risk of re-bleeding.
  • Antibiotics: Prophylactic antibiotics are recommended in patients with variceal bleeding to reduce the risk of bacterial infections, such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS): In patients with recurrent bleeding despite endoscopic and pharmacological therapy, TIPS may be considered to reduce portal pressure and prevent further bleeding.
  • Surgery: In rare cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to control variceal bleeding, particularly in patients with refractory bleeding or severe liver disease.

choices.text: Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations

questions.text: What are the potential observations that could be observed in this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of sensation over foot

 

In this case, the patient is likely to have a neuropathic/trophic ulcer, which is characterized by a lack of sensation over the foot due to peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are painless and have punched-out margins with the presence of calluses. The ulcer is located on the plantar surface of the foot (weight bearing area). The other options, such as decreased pulsations in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries, positive Trendelenburg sign, and pain on compression of calf, are not likely to be seen in this patient with a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Loss of sensation over the foot can lead to neuropathic/trophic ulcers as seen above. This is usually seen in neuropathies like Diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations: Decreased or absent posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulsations are indicative of vascular compromise or reduced blood flow to the lower extremity. This can lead to ischemic ulcers which are seen at tips of toes, web spaces, dorsum of foot etc. The image does not suggest an ischemic ulcer.

 

Option C. Positive Trendelenberg test: This is seen in varicose veins with saphenofemoral incompetence, and may have varicose ulcers above medial malleolus (Gaiter’s area). The image is not a case of varicose ulcer.

 

Option D. Pain on compression of calf: Pain on compression of the calf may indicate a potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to calf pain and swelling and venous ulcers. The image is not a case of DVT with venous ulcer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of sensation over the foot is a potential observation that could be observed in a patient with neuropathic/trophic ulcers.

questions.text: The most common site of acute limb ischemia from an embolic event is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Femoral Bifurcation

 

Explanation:

 

The femoral bifurcation is the most common site of acute limb ischemia from embolic events. Emboli typically originate from cardiac sources such as left atrial thrombus in atrial fibrillation or mural thrombus following myocardial infarction. These emboli travel through the arterial system until they lodge at points where vessels narrow significantly, with the femoral bifurcation being a prime location for emboli to become trapped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorto-iliac Bifurcation: While emboli at this location cause dramatic symptoms affecting both lower limbs simultaneously, they are less common than femoral emboli. Aortic bifurcation emboli typically cause bilateral symptoms with severe ischemia.

 

Option C. Popliteal Trifurcation: This is a more distal site where smaller emboli might lodge. While popliteal emboli do occur, they are less frequent than femoral emboli in acute limb ischemia presentations.

 

Option D. Brachial Artery: Upper extremity emboli are significantly less common than lower extremity emboli. The anatomical pathway from common cardiac sources naturally directs most emboli toward the lower limbs rather than the upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Embolic occlusions most frequently occur at the femoral bifurcation, presenting as unilateral acute limb ischemia with the classic signs: pain, pallor, pulselessness, paresthesia, and paralysis.

choices.text: From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the tragus to the xiphisternum.
From the ala of the nose to the angle of the mandible to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the ear lobule to the umbilicus

questions.text: What is the appropriate technique to measure the placement of a nasogastric tube? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.

 

This is the correct method. The nasogastric tube length is usually measured by estimating the distance from the tip of the nose, past the ear lobule (or the earlobe), and down to the xiphisternum (the point where the sternum meets the costal margin), also known as N-E-X rule. This method ensures that the tube is long enough to pass through the esophagus and reach the stomach without being too long to cause complications or too short to not be effective.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To determine the appropriate length of a nasogastric tube (also known as Ryle's tube) used for treating intestinal obstruction or providing nutritional support, the NEX method is commonly used, which involves measuring from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum. The approximate length to be inserted is around 55 cm. The preferred position for inserting the Ryle's tube is in a sitting position with the neck slightly flexed.

 

The proper positioning of the tube can be confirmed through auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air or by an abdominal radiograph. The ideal placement for an NG tube used for suction is within the stomach to avoid damage to the duodenum. In contrast, an NG feeding tube should be placed post-pyloric to reduce the risk of aspiration.

 

Indications for NG tube usage include gastric decompression in intestinal obstruction, aspiration of gastric fluid, nutritional support, and medication administration. However, some absolute contraindications to NG tube insertion include severe midface trauma and recent nasal surgery.

 

A tray of specialized instruments is used for nasogastric tube insertion, including a lubricating jelly, an NG tube, a syringe, and gloves, among others.

questions.text: Match the following cancers with their corresponding criteria for the minimum number of lymph nodes required for pathological staging: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The minimum number of lymph nodes required for accurate staging are 16 for stomach carcinoma, 12 for colon carcinoma, 6 for gall bladder carcinoma, and 10 for breast carcinoma.

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Taking CT scan of the patient

 

Taking CT scan of the patient: Incorrect. This is not part of the primary survey. After the primary survey, if the patient is stabilized, a secondary survey is conducted which is a more thorough examination and may involve advanced imaging like CT scans to further delineate injuries.

 

Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

 

Primary survey consists of five components, remembered by the mnemonic "ABCDE":

 

  1. Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection: The first step is to ensure the patient has a patent (open) airway, and to protect the cervical spine in case of potential injury.
  2. Breathing and ventilation: This step includes assessing the patient's breathing and ventilation. This can involve checking for symmetric chest rise, listening for breath sounds, and looking for any signs of respiratory distress or chest injury.
  3. Circulation with haemorrhage control: This involves assessing the patient's circulation and looking for signs of active bleeding. Measures such as fluid resuscitation may be initiated during this step if the patient is in shock.
  4. Disability: This involves a quick evaluation of the patient's neurological status, often using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS).
  5. Exposure/Environmental control: The patient should be fully undressed to allow a complete examination. However, care should be taken to prevent hypothermia, which can worsen outcomes in trauma patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measuring blood pressure: This is a part of assessing Circulation.

 

Option B. Removing clothes to inspect for wounds: This is a part of Exposure/Environmental control. It's crucial to remove clothing so that injuries aren't missed. However, while ensuring exposure, care should also be taken to maintain the patient's body temperature and prevent hypothermia.

 

Option D. Checking airway patency: This is part of Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection. Ensuring a clear airway is a top priority. Airway obstruction takes least time to death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary survey in trauma care includes Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure/Environmental control. Advanced imaging studies like CT scans are part of the secondary survey, conducted after initial stabilization.

questions.text:
What diseases' risk is elevated due to smoking? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Duct ectasia
  2. Fibroadenoma
  3. Mondor's disease
  4. Breast carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Cigarette smoking elevates the likelihood of experiencing duct ectasia, Mondor's disease, and breast carcinoma.

 

1. Duct ectasia: Typically seen in smokers. Patient presents with greenish Nipple discharge and Lump in breast with nipple retraction. Management is done by Conical excision of ductal system - Hadfield procedure.

 

3. Mondor's disease: Superficial thrombophlebitis of veins of breast / chest wall or axilla – males. Patient presents with cord like, thick, tender initially. Most common vein involves lateral thoracic vein. Smoking was identified as a possible contributing element in the development of Mondor's disease.

 

4. Breast carcinoma: Risk factors involve Age > 60, Early menarche (< 12 years), late menopause (>55 years), nulli-parity, late age of first child birth, Hormone replacement therapy, Inadequate breast feeding (breast feeding for > 12 months reduces risk), Alcohol & smoking consumption, obesity, Prior chest wall radiation, Family history.

 

Other Option:

 

2. Fibroadenoma: Tumor of breast arising from ductal epithelium or fibrous elements or both. It has two components – fibrous or stromal elements + glandular elements. Patient presents with slow growing lump (2-3cm), mobile like a mouse in breast. Smoking is not a risk factor for fibroadenomas.

questions.text: Calculate for Burn Surface Area (BSA) for a patent with burn involving the chest and abdomen right arm and right thigh (circumferental): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31.5% 

 

According to the ‘Rule of Nine’, BSA is calculated as: 

 

  • Chest and Abdomen = 18%
  • Right Arm (not entire upper limb) = 4.5%
  • Right Thigh = 9%

 

Total = 18% + 4.5% + 9% = 31.5%

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Rule of Nines is a method used to estimate the total body surface area affected by burns. It divides the body into sections that represent approximately 9% of the total surface area, facilitating quick and effective assessment and treatment planning for burn patients.

questions.text: A young female presents with pain in lower abdomen and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling, lateral and below the public tubercle. X-ray show intestinal obstruction. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strangulated femoral hernia

 

This type of hernia occurs just below the inguinal ligament, where the abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal. It is more common in women, especially those with repeated pregnancies. The description of the swelling's location lateral and below the pubic tubercle fits well with a femoral hernia. If the hernia becomes strangulated, it means that the blood supply to the herniated tissue is compromised, leading to severe pain, vomiting, and signs of intestinal obstruction as seen on X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adhesions: Bands of fibrous tissue that can form between abdominal tissues and organs, often as a result of surgery can lead to intestinal obstruction if they cause the intestines to twist or kink. However, adhesions themselves do not cause noticeable swelling as described in the scenario.

 

Option B. Strangulated inguinal hernia: This will present with a swelling above the pubic tubercle.

 

Option D. Appendicular mass: This refers to a mass formed from a swollen, inflamed appendix often associated with appendicitis. While this can lead to pain and vomiting, the location of the pain and swelling typically would be around the lower right quadrant of the abdomen, not below the pubic tubercle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the location of the swelling and the associated symptoms, the most probable diagnosis is a Strangulated Femoral Hernia. This condition requires prompt surgical intervention to relieve the obstruction and restore blood flow to the entrapped tissues to prevent further complications such as tissue necrosis.

choices.text: Penectomy with bilateral superficial inguinal dissection

questions.text: A Patient presented with a growth on the penis, which was diagnosed as a T3 cancer without lymph node metastasis. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penectomy with bilateral ilio-inguinal dissection

 

In the case of T3 penile cancer, the tumor has invaded the corpus cavernosum, indicating an advanced stage of the disease. The management of such advanced penile cancer requires aggressive treatment to control both the primary tumor and the potential spread to lymph nodes.

 

The recommended approach includes penectomy to remove the primary tumor and ilio-inguinal lymph node dissection as a prophylactic measure. This is because, even though there are no clinically detectable lymph node metastases (N0), the risk of micro-metastasis is significant in T3 cancers. Ilio-inguinal dissection encompasses both superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes and provides comprehensive regional control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penectomy: While penectomy addresses the primary tumor, it does not manage the risk of lymphatic spread, which is critical in advanced stages like T3. This option alone is insufficient for comprehensive cancer management.

 

Option B. Penectomy with superficial inguinal dissection: Superficial inguinal dissection alone is outdated and considered inadequate, as it does not address the deeper lymph nodes where metastasis may occur. Current guidelines favor a more extensive approach, including both superficial and deep nodes.

 

Option D. Penectomy with orchidectomy: Orchidectomy is not a part of the standard management for penile cancer, as it involves the removal of the testes and is relevant in testicular cancer, not penile cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For T3 penile cancer without lymph node metastasis, the standard management is penectomy along with ilio-inguinal lymph node dissection to address both the primary tumor and potential regional spread.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach extending into the head of the pancreas with metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

 

  • The clinical scenario involves carcinoma stomach infiltrating into the pancreas with liver metastasis.
  • Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy is the management of choice for such cases.
  • It is a type of palliative surgery that relieves the symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction caused by tumors in the distal stomach or duodenum.
  • The procedure allows food to bypass the obstruction and enter the small intestine, improving the patient's ability to eat and preventing malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option B. Radical gastrectomy: Radical gastrectomy involves the surgical removal of the stomach with the aim of curing the disease. This option is typically considered for localized gastric cancer that has not metastasized extensively.

 

Option C. Whipple's procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy): The Whipple's procedure is a complex surgical operation that involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the bile duct, and sometimes part of the stomach. It is typically performed for cancers located in the head of the pancreas, not stomach cancer.

 

Option D. Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy: This surgical approach involves the removal of the stomach (gastrectomy) and the right lobe of the liver. It might be considered if the tumor is locally advanced and involves both the stomach and liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with advanced gastric cancer extending into adjacent organs and with liver metastasis, the appropriate management often involves palliative measures, such as gastrojejunostomy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life, followed by chemotherapy.
  • Curative surgical options are generally not feasible in the presence of metastasis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old smoker presents with a history of five episodes of macroscopic hematuria, each lasting for about 4-5 days in the past five years. Which of the following investigations should be performed to evaluate the suspected diagnosis: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Urine microscopy and cytology

 

Explanation:

 

In a 55-year-old smoker presenting with multiple episodes of macroscopic hematuria, the primary concern is the possibility of carcinoma of the bladder. The first step in evaluating this patient is to perform urine microscopy and cytology, which are non-invasive and effective in detecting malignant cells in the urine.

 

Rationale:

 

  • Urine microscopy and cytology: This is a highly specific non-invasive test for detecting bladder cancer. It has a sensitivity of 40%-60% but a high specificity of over 90%, making it the preferred initial test for hematuria in patients with risk factors like smoking.
  • X-ray KUB: While useful for detecting stones and certain structural abnormalities, it is not sensitive or specific enough for detecting bladder cancer.
  • Ultrasound KUB: This imaging modality can detect structural abnormalities, but it may miss small or early bladder tumors.
  • DTPA scan: Primarily used for evaluating renal function, it is not appropriate for detecting bladder tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. X-ray KUB: Less sensitive and specific for bladder tumors.

 

Option C. Ultrasound KUB: May miss smaller bladder lesions; not the first-line investigation for suspected bladder cancer.

 

Option D. DTPA scan: Not relevant for detecting bladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a smoker with recurrent hematuria, urine microscopy and cytology are the most appropriate initial investigations to evaluate for bladder cancer.

questions.text: While doing endoscopy a constriction is noted at the level of 25 cm from incisors. Identify the probable cause of the constriction? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arch of aorta

 

During an endoscopy, constrictions of the esophagus can be identified at specific distances from the upper incisors. These constrictions are due to anatomical structures that come in close proximity to or cross the esophagus. At the level of 25 cm from the incisors, the probable cause of constriction is the arch of the aorta.

 

Anatomical Constrictions of the Esophagus:

 

  1. Junction with Cricopharynx (15 cm from incisors):
    • The first constriction occurs where the esophagus joins the cricopharynx, at approximately 15 cm from the upper incisors.
  2. Crossed by Arch of Aorta and Left Bronchus (25 cm from incisors):
    • The second constriction is due to the arch of the aorta and the left principal bronchus crossing the esophagus. This occurs at about 25 cm from the upper incisors.
  3. Diaphragmatic Hiatus (40 cm from incisors):
    • The third constriction occurs where the esophagus passes through the diaphragm, at around 40 cm from the upper incisors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Upper Bronchus: The left principal (main) bronchus, not the left upper bronchus, can contribute to the constriction at 25 cm from the incisors.

 

Option C. Right Upper Bronchus: The right upper bronchus does not cause a constriction in the esophagus.

 

Option D. Right Lower Bronchus: The right lower bronchus does not cause a constriction in the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constriction of the esophagus observed at 25 cm from the upper incisors during an endoscopy is most commonly due to the crossing of the esophagus by the arch of the aorta and the left principal bronchus.
